quotes.quote: A girl should be two things: classy and fabulous.

Elegance is a glowing inner peace. Grace is an ability to give as well as to receive and be thankful. Mystery is a hidden laugh always ready to surface! Glamour only radiates if there is a sublime courage & bravery within: glamour is like the moon; it only shines because the sun is there.
True class can never receive the highest grade..for its grade is endless.
Dressing well is a form of good manners.
I dress in a sophisticated and classy way - I always dress in a way I know my mother wouldn't be embarrassed to see.
You may be a princess or the richest woman in the world, but you cannot be more than a lady
Elegance is something more than ease--more than a freedom from awkwardness and restraint.--It implies precision, a polish, and a sparkling which is spirited, yet delicate.

Class is a mysterious essence that comes in many forms, depending on the woman. It largely comes from a woman’s sense of herself – from confidence without brashness, from courtesy, from kindness, and often includes a distinct sense of style – though that style can be unique and unconventional.
Tact is the ability to tell someone to go to hell in such a way that they look forward to the trip.

I am by no means a Proper Patty. My grandmother had many bones to pick with me, even as a three year old ('you are never too young for etiquette'). But I was raised with a certain standard that I considered 'the norm.' Manners and class went hand-in-hand. One did not exist without the other. However, in today's society, expecting 'the norm' is like looking for water in the desert.
Ah, dinner time. A time when you can class it up, or inadvertently do the opposite.
Respect for ourselves guides our morals, respect for others guides our manners.
Every woman is after a kind of classy image.
Being classy isn't a choice. Its a lifestyle.

Being classy is a culmination of being yourself, being positive, and doing good in all the places you can by all the means you can. Clothes, hair, music, film....none of these things a classy person make.
I don't consider myself a goody-goody, but I like to be perceived as classy.
Braininess is not attractive unless combined with some signs of elegance; class.
A truly elegant taste is generally accompanied with excellency of heart.
In character, in manner, in style, in all the things, the supreme excellence is simplicity.
We're very sensitive about what we do, or don't do. We're sassy and classy.
Dress shabbily and they remember the dress; dress impeccably and they remember the woman.
We have classy things and sexy things. We like to look pretty, no matter how big we get.
Simplicity is the ultimate sophistication.
Be classy. Anything but trashy.
The most sophisticated people I know - inside they are all children.
There is more to being classy than simply being stylish and confident. Being classy means always being kind, respectful and polite, even to those who are unkind to you.
She's just a very classy lady, always knows what to say and how to approach someone; she is very caring.
A guy wants a classy girl who is smart and has goals - someone that he wouldn't be afraid to bring home to his parents.
Beauty of style and harmony and grace and good rhythm depend on simplicity.
Respect is love in plain clothes.
The expression a woman wears on her face is more important than the clothes she wears on her back.
Being stylish is about enjoying your life and expressing yourself and your inner light.
Chic is when a woman is in harmony with herself.
Chic is a combination of style and fashion.
Being classy is my teenage rebellion.
It is not chic to be too chic.

A stylish person, for me, is one who draws your eye without necessarily being showy; they wear clothes that are beautifully cut, flatter the wearer, and show that they are not impervious to fashion, but not a slave to it either.
Always be a first rate version of yourself instead of a second rate version of somebody else.
Elegance is when the inside is as beautiful as the outside.
To be truly elegant one should not be noticed.
Elegant is not what you wear, and it's not about how you wear it, but it's more about who you are.
